::: {#hero-heading}
They are Ryan's favorite bookmarks, they cover everything from programming introductions to deep learning. If you have have a suggestion, please contact Ryan at one of the above links.
:::

## Data Science Resources

[An Introduction to Statistical Learning](https://www.statlearning.com/)

[The Elements of Statistical Learning](https://hastie.su.domains/Papers/ESLII.pdf)

[Foundations of Machine Learning](https://cs.nyu.edu/~mohri/mlbook/)

## R Resources

[R cookbook](http://www.cookbook-r.com/)

[R for Data Science](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/)

[Mastering Shiny](https://mastering-shiny.org/index.html)

[Tidy Modeling with R](https://www.tmwr.org/). My absolute favorite way to develop models.

## Python Resources

[A Whirlwind Tour of Python, by Jake VanderPlas](https://jakevdp.github.io/WhirlwindTourOfPython/) A solid introduction to Python, assuming you are already familiar with another programming language.

[Python Data Science Handbook](https://jakevdp.github.io/PythonDataScienceHandbook/)

[Pythex \| In-browser regex tester](https://pythex.org/)

## Data Visualization Resources

[From Data to Viz](https://www.data-to-viz.com/). A fantastic guide to all types of plots by Yan Holtz and Conor Healy. Also check out their [Dataviz Inspiration](https://www.dataviz-inspiration.com/) page.

[BBC Visual and Data Journalism cookbook for R graphics](https://bbc.github.io/rcookbook/#how_to_create_bbc_style_graphics)

[Cedric Scherer's Data Visualization & Information Design](https://cedricscherer.netlify.app/top/dataviz/)

## Data Engineering Resources

[The Ultimate Guide to Deploying a Shiny App on AWS, by Charles Bordet](https://www.charlesbordet.com/en/guide-shiny-aws/#). I personally used the guide to launch my own EC2 servers.

[Oh Shit, Git!?!](https://ohshitgit.com/) You've messed up. Bad. This resource might just save you.

[Intro to SQL: Querying and managing data](https://www.khanacademy.org/computing/computer-programming/sql)

## Math Resources

[Engineering Biostatistics: An Introduction Using MATLAB and WinBUGS by Brani Vidakovic](https://statbook.gatech.edu/statb4.pdf). Excellent resources for Bayesian statistics, MATLAB and WinBugs.

[Wolframe\|Alpha](https://www.wolframalpha.com/). Powerful in-browser computational aid.

[Symbolab](https://www.symbolab.com/). Another powerful in-browser computational aid. Usually provides steps to solve problems at no extra cost.

[Octave](https://octave-online.net/). Open source software to run those pesky .m scripts (Free alternative to MatLab)

[OpenBUGS](https://www.mrc-bsu.cam.ac.uk/software/bugs/openbugs/). Free Bayesian software. I prefer to use R or Python.

[Calculus Made Easy by S. P. Thompson](https://calculusmadeeasy.org/)

[Mathematics for Machine Learning](https://mml-book.github.io/book/mml-book.pdf)

[The Matrix Cookbook](The%20Matrix%20Cookbook)

[Introduction to Applied Linear Algebra](https://web.stanford.edu/~boyd/vmls/vmls.pdf)
